author: Tehelka Web Desk
title: Reliance arm acquires mutual fund business of Goldman Sachs India
text:
Comment 

Reliance Capital Asset Management (RCAM) on 21 October announced taking over mutual fund (MF) business of Goldman Sachs in India for Rs 243 crore even as as yet another player exited the Rs 13 lakh crore Indian mutual fund market. 
The transaction was okayed by the boards of two firms and is likely to be completed in this fiscal year, RCAM’s parent firm, Reliance Capital, said in a statement. 
“This acquisition is a significant step to strengthen both our businesses through selective growth,” said Sam Ghosh, executive director, Reliance Capital.“Along with GSAM India , we are confident of enhancing RCAM’s offerings to our investors,” he added. 
Under the deal, RCAM will get 12 onshore MF schemes of Goldman Sachs Asset Management (GSAM) India with total assets under management (AUM) worth Rs 7,132 crore, making Reliance Mutual Funds exclusive manager of the government’s Central Public Sector Enterprises (CPSE) Exchange Traded Fund (ETF). 
“We will ensure to maintain seamless continuity for all GSAM India investors across all schemes. Going forward we will consider more such acquisitions to complement our portfolio,” said RCAM CEO Sundeep Sikka. 
Reliance Capital is the financial services arm of Anil Ambani -led business conglomerate, Reliance Group and is involved in insurance, brokerage and wealth management among others. 
Goldman Sachs was given the mandate last year to manage CPSE ETF through which the government has raised Rs 4,000 crore by selling part of its stake in 10 central PSUs as part of its disinvestment programme. 
It may be noted Goldman Sachs Asset Management is one of the biggest fund managers with AUM of $1.19 trillion across countries. 
Reliance Mutual Fund is the largest asset manager in India with total AUM of more than Rs 2.5 lakh crore in areas of MF, pension funds, managed accounts and offshore funds. Goldman Sachs entered the Indian MF fund 2011 after acquiring Benchmark MF for Rs 120 crore. 
Initially, HDFC MF was in the race to acquire Goldman Sachs’ India MF assets, but lost out to Reliance MF. */
